title: 106_hr2462
content:
OPPORTUNITY FOR THE GOVERNMENT OF GUAM TO ACQUIRE EXCESS REAL PROPERTY IN GUAM. Transfer of Excess Real Property on Guam requires notification to the Government of Guam for potential acquisition within 180 days, otherwise, the property will be screened for Federal use or disposed of according to the Property Act. Conditions of transfer must be met for any real property transfer. Any transfer of excess real property to the Government of Guam must be for a public purpose and without further consideration. The transfer is subject to restrictive covenants to ensure compatibility with military activities, environmental conditions, access for environmental remediation, and use only for a public purpose. The transfer of excess real property to the Government of Guam must be for a public purpose and without further consideration. It is subject to restrictive covenants for compatibility with military activities, environmental conditions, and use only for a public purpose. The transfer is also subject to applicable Federal laws, with exceptions noted. The definitions of key terms are provided for clarity. The term "excess real property" refers to real property acquired by the United States before the enactment of relevant laws. The term "Guam National Wildlife Refuge" includes lands under Department of Defense jurisdiction. "Public purpose" refers to public benefit purposes for property disposal by the United States. The United States may dispose of property for public benefit purposes under specific regulations, excluding transfers for private use. Exemptions apply to certain real property on Guam, including transfers to the Coast Guard and within the Guam National Wildlife Refuge. The Administrator shall notify the Government of Guam and the Fish and Wildlife Service that the property has been declared excess. They have 180 days to discuss and reach an agreement on the future ownership and management of the real property. If an agreement is reached within 180 days, the property will be transferred and managed according to the agreement, which must be submitted to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the United States Senate and the appropriate committees of the United States House of Representatives. If parties do not reach an agreement within 180 days after notification of excess property, the Administrator will report to Congress with recommendations. Military department may transfer administrative control to General Services Administration with applicable terms. If parties do not reach an agreement within 180 days after notification of excess property, the Administrator will report to Congress with recommendations. In the event of transfer to the General Services Administration, the Department of the Interior will cover costs until final disposition. Any agreement on real property transfer must be transmitted to Congress at least 60 days prior to transfer. (E) Absent an agreement on the future ownership and use of the property, such property may not be transferred to another Federal agency or out of Federal ownership except pursuant to an Act of Congress specifically identifying such property. Real property described in the Guam Excess Lands Act shall be disposed of in accordance with the Act. Property on Guam declared excess as a result of a base closure law or facilities declared excess by the managing Federal agency for the purpose of transferring to another Federal agency must meet specific criteria for transfer. Dual Classification Property refers to real property with multiple classifications. (e) Dual Classification Property.--If a parcel of real property on Guam declared excess due to a base closure law is also within the Guam National Wildlife Refuge, it will be disposed of according to the base closure law. (f) The Administrator of General Services, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of the Interior, may issue necessary regulations to implement this section. SEC. 2. COMPACT IMPACT REPORTS. Section 104(e)(2) of Public Law 99-239 is amended to allow Governors of US territories or the State of Hawaii to report to the Secretary of the Interior annually on the impacts of compacts of free association. The Secretary of the Interior will review and forward these reports to Congress, and conduct a census of Micronesians every 5 years. The Governor can request assistance for conducting a census of Micronesians every 5 years, with a limit of $300,000 in annual expenditures. SEC. 3. APPLICATION OF FEDERAL PROGRAMS UNDER THE COMPACTS OF FREE ASSOCIATION. The freely associated states of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of Palau, and their citizens, remain eligible for Federal programs, grant assistance, and services of the United States. This eligibility continues through negotiations mentioned in the Compact of Free Association and during consideration of related legislation by Congress. The Housing Community Development Act of 1980 is amended to include lawful residents in the US under the Compacts of Free Association with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, with a provision that they do not receive preference over US citizens for assistance in Guam. The curr_chunk can be summarized as: 
"Speaker of the House of Representatives and Vice President of the United States."
